acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 72-hour ErC50 = 0.12mg/L for algae (Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata) (Test for the Ecological Effect of Chemical Substances (Ministry of the Environment), 1998), the substance was classified into Category 1.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Of rabbit LD50 values of 1260mg/kg and 660mg/kg (SIDS (accessed June 2008)), the smaller LD50 value was used as a basis to classify the substance into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Its rat LC50 (4hr) of > 0.107mg/L/4h (mixture of vapor and mist) (SIDS (accessed June 2008)) has been documented. However, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible" due to lack of other data.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the documented rat LD50 values of 3250mg/kg, 2100mg/kg, and 3990mg/kg (SIDS (accessed June 2008)), the substance was classified into "Not classified" using JIS classification criteria (Category 5 in the United Nations classification).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Dermal exposure tests, in which male mice were exposed throughout their lives, resulted in no detection of skin carcinogenicity (SIDS (accessed June 2008)). However, due to lack of other data, classification is not possible.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its classification for acute toxicity is Category 1 and it is not rapidly degradable (non-biodegradable, degradability based on OECD 301D-compliant, 4-week tests: 0% (SIDS, 2003)), the substance was classified into Category 1.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Its flash point is 150-160degC (SIDS (accessed June 2008)), which exceeds 93degC.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Micronucleus tests using erythrocytes of mice that underwent intraperitoneal administration (in vivo mutagenicity tests using somatic cells) yielded negative results (SIDS (accessed June 2008)). As such, the substance was classified into "Not classified". Among in vitro mutagenicity tests, some of the reverse mutation tests using bacteria yielded positive results depending on bacterial strains (SIDS (accessed June 2008)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds not containing oxygen or halogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Its autoignition point was 321degC (Chapman (2008)), which exceeds 70degC.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of data on reproductive and developmental toxicity.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: In the rabbit tests in which various concentrations and doses of the substance were applied to the eyes, the substance was evaluated to be moderately irritating with observation of corneal damage and iritis. In the tests in which 5 drops of the substance were applied, it caused severe burns and was evaluated to be highly irritating (SIDS (accessed June 2008)). In addition, its EU Risk Phrase is R34: causes burns and its pH is >= 11.5. From these results and since it is known to be skin corrosive, the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: In several rabbit tests (Draize tests, etc.), exposure to the undiluted substance for 4 hours resulted in necrosis in half or more animals and the substance was concluded to be corrosive (SIDS (accessed in June 2008)). In addition, its EU Risk Phrase is "R34: corrosive" and its pH is >= 11.5. From these, the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: In skin sensitization tests using guinea pigs (maximization tests), positive reactions were seen in 78% of treated animals (14 of 18 animals), concluding that the substance was sensitizing (SIDS (accessed in June 2008)). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Not much data from repeated exposure tests are available. In 4-week oral administration tests using rabbits, no systemic toxicity was detected at a high dose (200mg/kg/day), and its NOAEL was estimated to be 200mg/kg/day (SIDS (accessed June 2008)). However, since no other data were available, classification is not possible.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
